author: Odeinoichus
title: Disney Princess Palace Pets = Interesting Experiment
review:
Set #41069 Treasure’s Day at the Pool: Much like when LEGO Friends introduced us to the foil packed animal sets, Disney and LEGO decided to include a Palace Pets sub-theme known as Whisker Haven Tales. These are the pets of the Disney Princesses, and each one gets its own set. Are they a good idea? Do they add to the options and play values of the LEGO Disney theme? Let’s go over the set and discover this together.

Box/Instructions

Box: A very small box, similar to the sizes of the LEGO Friends animal based sets after the foil packs were phased out. This design has the same colouring as the LEGO Disney Princess theme, a rich pink colour with a picture of the numerous pets in the corner and the set showcased on the front. Overall a nice looking box design.

Instructions: These are pretty much what you’d expect. They are simple and easy to follow along with to build the models and feature some nice artwork in the back with the cross-promotions of the other Palace Pets sets featuring the princesses cuddling with their little animal friends.

Parts

There isn’t a lot of pieces in this set, nothing very unique or rare for parts pack fans, however it is a relatively cheap method of getting a few pink pieces and some nice clear blue elements, as well as the purple small leave element for trees.

Palace Pet

Treasure: This is Ariel’s pet cat, she’s a cute little red furred kitty designed to match with Ariel’s hair tone. She’s a completely new sculpted animal piece with a cute little purple mop of fur on top of her head to represent curly hair and a matching furry looking tail. There are holes on her head and in her tail to accommodate the standard peg-in accessories and she receives a pair of sunglasses in clear pink and a small yellow pinwheel shaped flower pin for her tail.

The build & completed model

Everything about this set’s build is relatively easy and quick to construct, you’ll find two small models and then a few extra accessory elements and display items. The build isn’t too exciting either since you’re making a small pool and outdoor vanity type model for an animal instead of a mini-doll.

Pool: A nice looking little model with a small diving board on one side that flips down on a hinged brick so Treasure can go swimming. It’s not much compared to other pool builds, but it’s relatively large and features some organic detailing with a small plant of some sort growing on one side. A small jumper plate can be used to fit Treasure inside the pool itself.

Additional Elements: The next largest model to play with is a small resting place where Treasure can sit on a pillow and enjoy a special treat, some pastry or other. It’s an ok model, but designed more for an animal piece and not a mini-doll. Then there’s a small little one-piece table where Treasure features an ice cream treat of some sort and a clear pink coffee mug? What does an animal need with a coffee mug?

There’s also a purse/basket with an ice-cream cone inside. Definitely an odd accessory to include when there are no mini-dolls in the set.

Overall opinion

I bought this out of curiosity and wanting to get every set from the Disney Princess theme, it was on sale and I picked it up because I liked the overall look of the elements involved for my Disney display. I’m also a sucker for kitties and Treasure is a great looking little animal piece.

I find myself conflicted though, as this has now retired it is decidedly not worth crazy prices one might find on the secondary market, there are no mini-dolls to go with it and it can be relatively easily built up using existing parts found in the LEGO Friends, Elves and Disney Princess themes.

So overall, I’m going to have to mildly recommend this set, and consider it an easy pass for builders that would prefer to collect Mini-Dolls and builds to play with instead of just little animal sets. It’s still fun, but ultimately not worth the full asking price.
